author: John Tierney is a staff writer for the Magazine.
body: It is a little late to be running a correction, but The New York Times owes one to the people who gathered at Brooklyn's City Hall on New Year's Eve 100 years ago. They met on that miserably cold, rainy night for an ''observance'' -- they specifically refused to call it a celebration -- of their city's merger with New York at midnight. Brooklyn's
title: Brooklyn Could Have Been A Contender

body: To the Editor: For the second time this year you have mistakenly identified places as being located in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, when in fact they were not. On March 9, you reported on Unity Fellowship Church on Classon Avenue, which was supposedly in Fort Greene, It was not. On Nov. 23, you focused on a stretch of Myrtle Avenue that is clearly
title: Pumping Pencils; Articles Were Off Mark On Fort Greene Boundaries

body: Eight people, including a 14-year-old girl and a 15-year-old boy, were arrested at an apartment in Coney Island, Brooklyn, yesterday, after a teen-age girl told the police that they had held her captive there for nearly a week, beating her and burning her with a clothes iron. The authorities said they were unsure what motivated the reported
title: Eight Arrested in the Imprisonment and Beating of a Girl, 15

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Scenes from the Malls: Megastores and Mini-Bazaars

title: Paid Notice: Deaths BOBETSKY, MARIE L. (NEE VUOLO)

body: A sweep of 21 electronics stores in New York City by the Department of Consumer Affairs found hundreds of violations, ranging from misrepresenting prices to selling used items as new, according to findings released yesterday. The agency said that 20 of the stores incurred 671 violations during a two-week period in November. One of the most common
title: Metro Business; City Finds Violations At Electronics Stores

body: SOHO Memento Mori, In Photographs A few painted words and dates tell a story of a life cut short: ''Anthony RIP 6-15-76 9-17-95.'' This somber message painted on a Brooklyn storefront was captured by Larry Racioppo, a photographer who remembers those who remember. In a series of 20 large color photographs like the one below, he has documented
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Tanya Smith stood over the Macy's glass counter at the Fulton Street Mall in downtown Brooklyn, admiring an assortment of pearl necklaces, earrings and bracelets. Ms. Smith asked to see a necklace with a diamond and gold pendant. But after a few moments, she put it back and went on to look around the cavernous store. ''It's beautiful,'' the
title: No Sign of Hangover On the Day After; Bracelets and Bargains

body: FOR CHILDREN Theater ''LOST AND FOUND,'' presented by the Puppet Company, is a story about a lost doll that meets a variety of puppet characters on her journey home. Performances are every Saturday and Sunday through April at 1 and 3 P.M., at the Puppet Company, 31 Union Square West, corner of 16th Street, Loft 2B. Tickets: $7.50; reservations
title: SPARE TIME

body: The Young Spring Farm grocery on 125th Street in Harlem is a Thanksgiving dinner waiting to happen. There are wet bundles of collards, and orange piles of yams, and yellow turnips the size of softballs. And so yesterday, Sherri Softli, needing yams for her sweet potato pie, rushed in, then rushed home to her kitchen to cook into the early morning.
title: For Some, a Holiday Rush; for Others, Just Another Day

body: WARDWELL-Frederic Koppe. Of Brooklyn, NY, died November 24, 1997. Husband of Frances Jacoby Wardwell (deceased); father of Paul Wardwell. Served in WWII, United States Merchant Service. Graduate of The University of Chicago. He is survived by his son Paul and sisters Dorothy, Kathryn, Marjorie and Laura. Visitation 7-9 PM, Wednesday, November 26,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WARDWELL, FREDERIC KOPPE

body: New York City police officers will be permitted to wear their uniforms while working off duty in a pilot program to start in February, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. Under the plan, the Police Department will assign officers who request off-duty work to private employers, said Marilyn Mode, the department's Deputy Commissioner for Public
title: Uniforms to Be Allowed For Moonlighting Officers

body: Eel-Isaiah Bellamy didn't get the warm welcome he expected when he opened his tailoring shop, 4UII Wear on Myrtle Avenue in 1995, and he soon discovered why. The previous tenant had been selling drugs, he said, and old-timers assumed Mr. Bellamy would do the same. When it became clear that he was a ''young black man doing something positive,'' as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FORT GREENE; Slow Going For Recovery On Myrtle

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A Brooklyn mother died at Kings County Hospital Center at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, hours after her estranged husband shot her four times with an AK-47 assault rifle during a domestic dispute, the police said. Shortly after 10:30 A.M. the victim, Sherry Roach, 25, brought the couple's two children, aged 4 months and 7, to see her husband, Reginald
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Woman Dies of Gunshots After a Domestic Dispute

body: A Brooklyn woman was charged with attempted murder yesterday after she tried to remove the breathing and feeding tubes from her 22-month-old daughter, who was in the hospital after being scalded in a tub of hot water last week, the police said last night. The girl, Isis Moore, died at the hospital early yesterday. A cause of death had not yet been
title: Mother Accused of Trying to Pull Life-Support Tubes of Girl Who Later Died

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: ''THIS is a tragedy!'' Ed Levine moans, craning his neck as the car speeds down Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn. ''Did you see that? There's a FOR RENT sign in Gerace's bakery. It can't be!'' He begins a keening wail, a lament for a lost bakery. ''Oh, my God. This drives me crazy. That place has been in Coney Island forever. They taught me how to make
title: Critic's Notebook; On an Odyssey With the Homer Of Rugelach

body: To the unemployed refugees who were its clients, the Albanian American Civic Association in the Bronx seemed to offer a much-needed helping hand. When they visited its storefront on Astor Avenue, they would receive stacks of brochures, chat with a ''job developer'' and fill out detailed forms. Then they would go home to await calls for job
title: 3 Aid Groups For Refugees Are Charged With Fraud

body: It wasn't exactly pressing the flesh, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani found his own characteristic way to wrap up his re-election campaign: an exultant 48-hour night and day tour of the city beginning yesterday on the back of his open-air bus. Cruising the streets of all five boroughs in sunlight, drizzle and darkness, the Mayor spent most of
title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYOR; Upbeat Giuliani Takes A Lap Around the City

author: Bruce McCall is a freelance writer and illustrator and the author of ''Thin Ice: Coming of Age in Canada.''
body: More than any other team of that era, the Dodgers fielded a nine-man lineup. Snider, Hodges, Robinson, Furillo, Campanella, Reese, Marshal Blucher, Lamont Cranston, Sir Humphry Davy, Alfred Apaka and the Surf Riders: they all meld together, in memory's crepuscular gloaming, into that something some call ''Dodgerness.'' Which, by the bye, was
title: BOOKEND; Absolutely the Last Dodger Memoir Ever

body: Confronting pelting rain, bursts of wind and often small crowds, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger headed into the final weekend of their campaign yesterday, as Mr. Giuliani again played what he considers his political trump card -- the latest decrease in crime -- while Ms. Messinger warned that things were not as good as they seemed.
title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CANDIDATES; RAIN AND APATHY DOG MAYORAL RACE AS IT WINDS DOWN

body: Two men, charged with raping a teen-age girl in Brooklyn, and a third man, who was said to have boasted that he was a member of the Bloods gang, were charged yesterday with plotting to murder the girl to keep her from testifying in the rape case. But the plot was foiled before any attempt was made on the girl's life, law enforcement officials said
title: 3 Charged With Plotting to Kill Teen-Age Rape Victim

body: This Sunday, at 10:35 A.M., 30,463 entrants will lay claim to the city's streets for the 28th New York City Marathon. The 26.2-mile course, full of landmarks, historical sites and ethnic neighborhoods, will take them through all five boroughs and across five bridges. Here is a guide for spectators. TELEVISION/RADIO WPIX (Channel 11) will broadcast
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON: SPECIAL PREVIEW SECTION; More Than 30,000 Reasons to Watch

title: Paid Notice: Deaths GORDON, GEORGE

body: Follow Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn with enough persistence, and eventually you wind up at Floyd Bennett Field. This is the end of the line, an abandoned airport where the wind swirls and whips, disturbing the ghosts of Amelia Earhart, Howard Hughes and Wiley Post, the fliers who helped make Floyd Bennett Field a symbol of the romance of aviation.
title: >New York And Its Wealth Of Nature (Really!)

body: Dolph Camilli, a slugging first baseman who propelled the Brooklyn Dodgers to a long-awaited pennant in 1941 and became one of the most popular players in Flatbush, died yesterday in San Mateo, Calif. He was 90. Noted for his muscular physique and soft hands, Camilli hit 34 home runs, drove in 120 runs (both National League highs) and fielded
title: Dolph Camilli, Who Led Dodgers to '41 Pennant, Dies at 90

body: Gazing at his customers suspiciously, Mun Chae paced along the rows of eggplants, green plantains, bell peppers and other vegetables stacked neatly on the shelves of Chae Fruit and Vegetable Market. Then Mr. Mun, the manager of the store, zeroed in on a familiar face, a large Haitian woman who was clutching a straw basket under her arms and
title: Something in Common; To Bridge a Gap, Korean Grocers Try a Little Creole

body: An off-duty police officer was shot last night in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, after a dispute broke out in a nightclub, the police said. The officer, whom the police did not identify, was shot once in the hip and was listed in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center. Officer Dennis Laffin said the incident occurred at 11:30 P.M. at Club Oui
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Off-Duty Police Officer Is Shot at a Nightclub

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted in the 19th century to a Victorian cottage, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. On view indefinitely is the photographer's parlor, filled with period furniture. The exhibition ''Traveling With Alice
title: Spare Times

body: Phil Myers emerged from the Jamaica Center subway station into a chilly drizzle Wednesday morning, 50 feet from where a row of dollar-a-ride vans waited to whisk him home to Laurelton, Queens. But Mr. Myers, a 50-year-old postal worker in Manhattan, has not set foot in a commuter van since July, when the Transit Authority began offering free
title: Saving That Dollar; Free Bus Transfers Mean Fewer Fares for Vans

body: The New York City mayoral contest became entangled in ethnic politics yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked Ruth W. Messinger for skipping a Columbus Day Mass, while she tried to reassure Jewish voters concerned about her public embrace of the Rev. Al Sharpton. The confluence of ethnic forces focused mostly on Ms. Messinger and came on
title: Heat of Ethnic Politics Is Felt In New York Race for Mayor

body: LARRY FOX, the owner of a small Brooklyn company that distributes paper products to party-supply stores, grew up in Flatbush but until recently had not been near the waterfront in Sunset Park in 10 years. He had been storing goods in Kearny, N.J., although he garaged his trucks on Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn, and he was looking for a place in which
title: PERSPECTIVES; A Leasing Pickup on the Brooklyn Waterfront

body: To the Editor: Thank you for the wonderful article on Community Gardens, ''World's Fair of Gardens Grow at the City's Doorstep'' (Sept. 25). We should all commit those wonderful color photos to memory, for soon there will be no gardens left to treasure. Just last week, our Brooklyn Bear's Community Garden, at Pacific Street and Flatbush Avenue, was
title: A Disappearing Garden

body: The Islamic Angle Q. The Islamic Cultural Center at 96th Street and Third Avenue sits at a peculiar angle on its site, its axis turned diagonally away from the Manhattan street grid. Is there some religious significance to this? A. Yes. The opulent building, like every mosque around the world, is oriented toward the qiblah, the direction of the
title: F.Y.I.

author: Katie Roiphe is a New York author whose most recent book is ''Last Night in Paradise.''
body: My father left Flatbush 55 years ago, and now, on a bright fall day, I find myself going back to deepest Brooklyn, to Coney Island, to the last stop on the F train. My date stops in front of the Cyclone that curls ominously above us. I am astonished that he wants to ride it. I feel twinges of panic on elevators and airplanes. But it seems too early
title: MY NEW YORK; On a Soaring Ride Of Reminiscence, Speed and Wonder

body: The police say the incident began when a 27-year-old college student named Jens Nerestant stood in front of a police cruiser one late night last summer in St. Albans, Queens, and took a defiant swig from a 40-ounce bottle of beer. Witnesses say it started differently, when a police sergeant lifted Mr. Nerestant's beer from a brown paper bag,
title: One Incident, Two Accounts; Insubordinate Officer or Peacemaker? A Matter of Perception

body: LINKER-Blanche Silverman. Born on June 18, 1929. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt. Passed Tuesday, September 30, leaving a void in our lives. Her strength was an inspiration to us all. Services today at 1 PM, Parkside, Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LINKER, BLANCHE SILVERMAN

body: DON'T bother to shush. title: For Libraries, a Time of Rebirth

body: A Federal judge yesterday rejected the Rev. Al Sharpton's bid for a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary, but the judge unleashed a harsh attack on the city's Board of Elections for what he called its ineptitude in handling the Sept. 9 primary. The ruling by Judge Denny Chin of the Southern District of New York left a jubilant Ruth W. Messinger
title: Judge Denies Sharpton Bid For Runoff

body: A Brooklyn man has made new allegations of police abuse against Justin A. Volpe, the police officer charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in the bathroom of the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn last month. The man, Kingsley Rodgers, 18, filed a $4 million civil suit on Aug. 29 in United States District Court in Brooklyn against
title: New Allegations of Abuse For Officer in Torture Case

body: After the 14th reported rape this year in Greenwich Village -- one of the few New York City neighborhoods where the number of rapes, robberies and other violent crimes is rising -- residents and community groups are voicing concern that some of the rapes may be copycat crimes. Of the 14 rapes -- more than triple the total for all of 1996 --
title: Fears of Copycat Rapes in Greenwich Village After 14th Attack Is Reported

body: September * DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM The company returns after a two-year absence from its home city with a new crop of spirited young ballerinas and an ambitious four-program season featuring new works by John Alleyne, Robert Garland and Vincent Sekwati Mantsoe, John Taras's vivid restaging of ''The Firebird,'' and dances by Glen Tetley, Alonso
title: DANCE

body: Ruth Messinger could hardly have looked more alone. She had just come out of P.S. 249 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn and now she was stopping to talk to three or four reporters. It was a fine day for campaigning. The afternoon was sunny and mild and traces of autumn were appearing. With the Democratic mayoral primary just days away, it
title: The Lonely Campaign

body: Events yesterday in the Democratic mayoral primary campaign in New York City. RUTH W. MESSINGER Ms. Messinger began the day with some old-fashioned electioneering, shaking hands with subway riders during the early morning rush at the Newkirk Avenue station in Flatbush, Brooklyn. Later, she attended a news conference outside City Hall, where she
title: On the Trail

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to march in his fifth West Indian American Day parade tomorrow, taking part in a buoyant festival that for the most part has steered clear of politics. But this year, with the Abner Louima brutality case the talk not only of West Indians but of the entire city, the annual celebration is expected to take on a more
title: Mood Turning Political For West Indian Parade

body: Master Keys Q. What exactly is the ''key to the city'' that the Mayor presents to visiting dignitaries and champion athletes? Can copies be made? A. Probably not. The ''key to the city'' is actually an oversized reproduction of the 1812 key to City Hall. The practice of presenting a key to an honored guest of the city dates back to medieval times,
title: F.Y.I.

body: Jaw clenched, hands clasped and eyes focused straight ahead, Sgt. Gregory Fors didn't flinch when two marchers in yesterday's protest against police brutality began waving a Jamaican flag an inch from his nose. ''K.K.K., go away!'' screamed one of the marchers, Michael Brown of Flatbush, Brooklyn. The sergeant took a deep breath. ''New York Plunger
title: Facing Storm of Rage, Officers Are Impassive

body: Because of the march today protesting police brutality, which is expected to attract thousands of people, roadways across downtown Brooklyn and near City Hall will be clogged. Traffic delays are expected in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn Bridge from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and around City Hall and the Manhattan side of the bridge between noon and 6 P.M. The
title: Traffic Alert

body: Two Haitian organizations are expecting thousands of people to march from Brooklyn to Manhattan tomorrow morning to protest police brutality, and the demonstration has generated support from other civic and minority groups, officials said. The march, organized by the Haitian American Alliance and Haitian Enforcement Against Racism, will begin at
title: Haitians Expect Thousands To March Against Brutality

body: Brooklyn residents who heard a 13-year-old girl screaming early yesterday morning chased and caught a man who she said had raped her, the police and witnesses said. The police arrested Martin Frederick, 32, of 1424 Flatbush Avenue, in Flatbush, and charged him with rape, sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child. The girl, whose name was not
title: Neighbors Chase and Seize Rape Suspect

body: MIDTOWN Tugboat Racing on Hudson For Real Power-Boat Action Tugboats may not be built for speed, but they will be racing in the Hudson River next Sunday as the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum holds its fifth annual tugboat contest. The day's events, which can be seen best from the Intrepid's flight deck, will begin with a parade of tugs at 12:25
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: MANHATTAN INWOOD $95,000 65 Park Terrace East 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,050-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; elevator, eat-in kitchen, sunken living room, 400-sq.-ft. terrace; maintenance $890, 34% tax-deductible, listed at $89,000 (multiple bids) 1 1/2 years on market (Broker: New Heights) UPPER EAST SIDE $682,500 1175 York Avenue (63d St.) (New
title: Residential Resales

body: His name has been invoked by street protesters and mayoral candidates. He has been the focus of outraged editorials and national news coverage. For many immigrant and minority New Yorkers, he is the latest victim of a criminal-justice system that is too often a foe, not a protector. But at the center of this storm, Abner Louima's main concerns are
title: In Hospital, Immigrant Gives Views On Brutality

body: Prosecutors investigating charges that a Haitian immigrant was brutalized at a Brooklyn police station are widening their inquiry in two directions, investigators said last night: they are trying to determine whether officers in the precinct tried to cover up the attack, and examining allegations that two other officers beat a second Haitian
title: Investigators Looking at New Allegations in Brutality Case

body: After a four-and-a-half-month investigation, the New York Police Department's air bag theft task force raided a Brooklyn automotive shop yesterday morning and arrested 21 people who were charged with possessing stolen property, the police said. During the 11 A.M. raid on V Engines, at 8002 Foster Avenue in East Flatbush, police officers discovered
title: 21 at Repair Shop Arrested in Thefts of Air Bags and Auto Parts

body: PLANDING-Barbara A., of Brooklyn (former administrative assistant in the rheumatology department Downstate Medical Center) on August 17th. Beloved daughter of the late Andrew and Mary (nee Taylor) Planding. Devoted sister of Andrew Planding. Also survived by 2 nieces and two grand nieces. Funeral from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths PLANDING, BARBARA A.

body: The choir sang the French hymns with even more spirit than usual, and the parishioners' shouts of ''Amen!'' and ''Hallelujah!'' seemed to shake the church's brick walls. And the preacher's voice, normally soft, thundered across the pews. ''Blessed are you when men revile you and persecute you,'' the Rev. Philias Nicolas 2d told the congregation at
title: New York Haitians Sensing Betrayal in a Land of Refuge

body: A second police officer from the 70th Precinct has come forward to give investigators an account of the sexual assault of a Haitian immigrant who was seriously injured on Aug. 9 at the hands of his police captors, a law enforcement official said yesterday as the police prepared to arrest at least two more officers in the attack. The new witness,
title: 2d Officer Gives Account Of Sex Assault of Haitian

body: DRUG-RELATED violence once ruled a stretch of Sixth Avenue in Sunset Park. Three years ago, on the corner at 52d Street, a drug dealer killed a rival teen-age drug seller, firing two bullets into the back of his head. Two years ago, down the street, another teen-ager was held to the ground by rival drug dealers and slashed in the face dozens of
title: Where Has Your Neighborhood Drug Dealer Gone?

body: Thousands of demonstrators, many waving toilet plungers or Haitian flags, marched through Flatbush, Brooklyn, to the 70th Precinct yesterday, protesting the torture there of a Haitian immigrant and assailing the Giuliani administration's record on police brutality. The loud but peaceful protest, the most vocal show of anger yet over the beating of
title: THOUSANDS MARCH TO PROTEST POLICE

body: A second New York City police officer has been charged with brutally attacking a Haitian immigrant inside a Brooklyn station house last weekend, officials announced last night, adding that the essential information used against the officer was provided by one of his colleagues at the 70th Precinct. Officer Charles Schwarz was named in an indictment
title: 2D POLICE OFFICER CHARGED IN ATTACK ON ARRESTED MAN

body: INTERNATIONAL 3-5 Mutant Seaweed Afflicts Mediterranean Waters The luxuriant but toxic meadows spawned by Caulerpa taxifolia have defeated navies and ravaged eco systems all across the Mediterranean. Scientists now hope a Caribbean snail can stop the relentless progress of the weed, accidentally brewed in a German zoo from an exotic Pacific
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: There are at least two views of the officers of the 70th Precinct, a narrow strip of Brooklyn that is as ethnically diverse as anywhere in the city, spanning from old-line Irish to Pakistani newcomers, to Jews and Caribbean blacks. One view is told by the numbers: serious crime has dropped by 51 percent over the last four years and by 14 percent
title: Some Residents Wary of the 'Laws of Flatbush'

body: Responding to allegations that police officers tortured a man in custody inside the station house of Brooklyn's 70th Precinct last weekend, Police Commissioner Howard Safir swept the precinct clean yesterday, reassigning its 2 top supervisors, suspending a desk sergeant and placing 10 other officers on desk duties. In announcing the shake-up
title: Leaders of Precinct Are Swept Out in Torture Inquiry

body: A 25-year-old police officer was charged last night with assaulting and brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in a Brooklyn station house bathroom after arresting him in a street scuffle, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that other officers might also be arrested. The arrest culminated a long day of news conferences, protests and talk-radio outrage
title: OFFICER CHARGED IN MAN'S TORTURE AT STATION HOUSE

body: Police Officer Justin Volpe, 25, followed his father into police work and landed a job on the midnight tour, patrolling the streets of Flatbush, Brooklyn. Now he stands accused of assault and sexual abuse for allegedly tormenting and critically injuring a man he had taken into custody. Until details began to emerge on Tuesday about the reported
title: Differing Views of Policeman Accused of Assaulting Man in Custody

body: On a typical morning, Radio Soleil D'Haiti, a Haitian cable radio station that broadcasts from a storefront in Brooklyn, offers light entertainment, usually the undulating rhythms of peppery compas music. But yesterday, things were far from normal. The station opened its phone lines for what became hours of bitter calls about a Haitian man who, his
title: Protest Call: 'Something Has to Be Done'

body: After James Halversen, a 30-year-old New York City firefighter, was shot to death on a Friday night last January while jogging with his golden retriever on the track at Centereach High School, detectives were baffled. While the Long Island crime scene clearly showed that Mr. Halversen had been a gunman's intended target, investigators could find no
title: In Murder Of Firefighter, An Arrest But No Motive

body: Prosecutors are investigating allegations that police officers beat and tortured a man while he was in custody at a Brooklyn station house, officials said yesterday. Two officers were placed on modified duty last night, meaning that their guns have been taken away and they have been put on desk jobs while the case is investigated by the Brooklyn
title: Injured Man Says Brooklyn Officers Tortured Him in Custody

body: On Friday afternoon, Abner Louima telephoned his younger brother, Jonas, and begged him to come visit him at the water and sewage treatment plant near Spring Creek Park in eastern Brooklyn where he works as a security guard. The younger brother said that he was ill but that Mr. Louima was persistent. ''I told him, actually I am not feeling well, I
title: Family Describes a Readily Friendly Man

body: Clinton Hill is home to brownstones and black professionals, to the Pratt Institute and public housing projects. Now a pioneering group of Hasidim have been blended into that mix as well. Close to 40 Satmar families -- some 300 people -- have left the overcrowded confines of Williamsburg to take up residence in a former factory renovated
title: Hasidic Pioneers Set Forth From Williamsburg to Seek Space Across a New Frontier

body: HOFFMAN-Sally (Linitz), 88. Beloved mother of Stephen and the late Doris, sister of Lynn, grandmother of Aaron and Judith, aunt of Carol, Diane, Alice, Blanche, Harvey, Lewis and Rosalind. Devoted wife of the late Harry. We deeply mourn her loss. Services Monday, August 11, at 1:30 PM, at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HOFFMAN, SALLY (LINITZ)

body: ABOUT 30 years ago, a sculpture revolution broke out in New York City that led many artists to abandon galleries and museums for points unknown, most of them outdoors. Artists like Michael Heizer, Robert Smithson and Walter De Maria ended up in the Southwest, while others, like Richard Serra, Donald Judd and Gordon Matta-Clark, executed various
title: Sculpture Adorns the Urban Terrain

body: Engineers for the city and the landlords of a five-story building in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn yesterday offered starkly different explanations for the building's collapse, as tenants claimed belongings rescued from debris by the police. Sixty-seven adults and 32 children narrowly escaped after police officers and firefighters roused
title: Dispute Emerges on Cause of Brooklyn Building Collapse

body: ''PETER PAN,'' an original production based on the J. M. Barrie classic, performed outdoors by Expanded Arts Inc. with dance movements that evoke flying. Sundays at 3 P.M. through Aug. 24. On Sunday at Pier 84 at West 44th Street, Clinton; Aug. 17 at Pier 54 at West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, and Aug. 24 at Pier 25 at North Moore Street, lower
title: Keep in Mind

body: The corner of a five-story apartment building in Brooklyn collapsed early yesterday, raining tons of debris into the street and sending firefighters and police officers racing through the halls to warn scores of sleeping residents to get out. City officials said yesterday that it appeared the collapse, which left three people injured, was caused by
title: Dozens Narrowly Escape as Apartment Building Falls

body: A copy of a threatening note found last Thursday in the Brooklyn apartment of two men accused of planning bomb attacks had been mailed two days earlier to a Federal program that offers rewards for information on terrorists, State Department and law enforcement officials said last night. The disclosure deepened the mystery over the alleged bombing
title: State Dept. Got Bomb Note, but Doesn't Know Why

body: Ending weeks of negotiation, the Giuliani administration and the City Council reached an agreement yesterday that will allow a private van service in Brooklyn to operate along Flatbush Avenue, shuttling customers for $1 a ride to areas underserved by public transportation. The service, Brooklyn Van Lines, will be allowed to operate with 20 vans
title: Deal Is Reached to Allow a Van Service to Operate in Brooklyn

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS Anonymous Sculpture On Ordinary Buildings The gargoyles, mermaids and various other carvings adorning the city's stonework often go unmentioned in guidebooks, because the artisans were not well known. Brooklyn Heights is one neighborhood where they can be seen in force, where immigrant artisans with small machine tools made
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: New Medical Center Focuses On Treating Breast Diseases In an attempt to coordinate the diagnosis and treatment of breast diseases more effectively, a group of physicians from New York University Medical Center and from the Mid Manhattan Medical Associates, a private group, this month opened Comprehensive Breasthealth of New York at 654 Madison
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.

body: Brooklyn Van Lines has won the latest political skirmish over its right to operate, but the war over commuter vans is likely to continue. Last Monday, Mayor Giuliani vetoed the City Council's rejection of the company's application to operate 40 ''dollar vans,'' whose name derives from the fare they charge, along Flatbush Avenue. Mr. Giuliani has
title: Veto Aids a 'Dollar Van' Line

body: Severe thunderstorms flashed across the metropolitan region yesterday, knocking down power lines and uprooting trees in bursts of high winds, rain and lightning that left three people dead and provided a violent and disruptive finale to the first heat wave of the summer. Two of the dead were construction workers who were killed last night when
title: Summer Storms Sweep Region; 3 People Dead

body: In the second such accident in two weeks, the last car of a subway train derailed at a switch early yesterday in Brooklyn, leaving four people injured and the car itself damaged beyond repair. Even as officials began examining yesterday's accident, which involved a southbound No. 2 train leaving the Franklin Avenue station, investigators said they
title: Another Crash In the Subway Leaves 4 Hurt

body: Four years ago, Anthony D. Weiner cruised easily to victory in the Democratic primary for the City Council race, facing only token opposition. But to hear several people in the quiet, residential neighborhoods of southern Brooklyn tell it, Mr. Weiner is not likely to have such an untroubled race this year. Mr. Weiner, the 32-year-old incumbent from
title: Congress a Backdrop to Council Race

body: A 57-year-old professor died after she was struck by a van yesterday morning while she was riding a bicycle in Prospect Park. Bicyclists and joggers have been pressing for years to remove all motor vehicle traffic from the Brooklyn park, which is mostly closed to automobiles on weekends as well as during certain hours on weekdays. The woman, Rachel
title: Bicyclist Killed When Van Hits Her in Prospect Park

body: ''We're cleaning up this community, but Bay Ridge is the cleanest community in Brooklyn,'' said one criminal removing graffiti from the Bay Ridge monastery wall last Sunday as part of his probation. ''My community'' -- he lives in Flatbush -- ''needs cleaning up more than this. Why don't we clean up our own communities?'' Over the last five years,
title: How a Community Gets Community Service: Being Organized Helps

body: One of the worst traffic days of the year was made even rougher yesterday when a brush fire shut the Belt Parkway for several hours in both directions at Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. The fire was brought under control by the afternoon, but it snarled the roads during the heaviest holiday traffic. It broke out in Floyd Bennett Field around 11:57
title: Stubborn Brush Fire Shuts Part of Belt Parkway, Snarling Traffic

body: To the Editor; Before New York City grants applications to license van operators (editorial, June 26), the Police Department should clear the uninsured pirate operators clogging the streets near shopping strips like Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. We should offer the carrot of licenses only after we have at least shown the stick of enforcement.
title: Punish Those Pirates

body: Lisa Williams considers herself a model immigrant. After health problems forced her to give up her job as a nursing assistant, Ms. Williams, who is 27 and from the West Indies, bought a used 11-seat gray Ford Econoline van with a friend and started a business. The van is now one of the hundreds of illegal vans that shuttle along Flatbush Avenue
title: Vans Still on an Uphill Road

body: In 1972, when Nancy Cogen opened the Melting Pot, a tie-dye clothing store on Atlantic Avenue, great expectations were in the air. A group of young entrepreneurs was renovating storefronts, with the idea of creating a pleasant shopping district. ''The hope was that there would be stores, and people would stroll the avenue,'' Ms. Cogen said. ''We
title: On Atlantic Avenue, Another Boom, at Least in Optimism

body: WHEN the Regional Plan Association published a study in 1983 arguing that the way to reverse the deterioration of downtown Brooklyn was to turn it into the city's third central business district, after downtown and midtown Manhattan, the outcome was anything but certain. The uncertainties continued over the years even as the cluster of buildings
title: A Dream Grows in Brooklyn

body: Charlene Heyliger is moving her clothes shop, Gourd-Chips Boutique, from its present location on Atlantic Avenue. She is going to try her luck on Court Street, which does not have all the traffic problems. ''Had I realized about the parking I would not have come here,'' said Ms. Heyliger, who has been on Atlantic near Bond Street for five years.
title: Merchants vs. Drivers on Atlantic Avenue

body: BERKOWITZ-Alexander. Loving husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Sondra, Michael and Ilene. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Funeral service Tuesday, 9:45 A.M., at I.J. Morris 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

body: LET us now praise famous museums, or at least a single great one: the Brooklyn Museum, recently rechristened the Brooklyn Museum of Art. First, hats off to its history. Between this year and next, the museum will celebrate two anniversaries: 175 years as a public institution, and a century of residence in its splendid Beaux-Arts home on Eastern
title: Wandering The World While Still In Brooklyn

body: Seeing Double Q. Aside from the drama they provide as an architectural backdrop to the park, is there a reason why so many apartment buildings on Central Park West have twin towers? A. title: F.Y.I.

body: British Country Sweaters Return Wearing a New Label Upper East Siders who can't stand to wear what anyone else is wearing can rest assured that Sportsworks, the shop that sold one-of-a-kind hand-knitted British sweaters at 1046 Madison Avenue at 80th Street for more than 20 years, plans to return in August just two blocks away. title: NEW YORKERS & CO.

body: Trolleys were once so characteristic of Brooklyn that the local professional ball club started out as the ''Trolley Dodgers.'' Yet it has been 40 years since Brooklyn streets have felt the rumble of the capsule-shaped cars or heard the ring of their bells. That all changed on May 1, when a 37-year-old Flatbush native, Bob Diamond, took a major step
title: Trolley Lover Rolls Closer To a Dream

body: AS a child, Beatrice Stein spent summers in country houses in various parts of France, surrounded by members of her immediate and extended family. Besides her parents, there was usually a collection of cousins, some of whom might not have been able to summer elsewhere. So when Mrs. Stein, a lawyer, read an article about the Fresh Air Fund in The
title: Family Welcomes Back Fresh Air Fund Guest

body: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy was shot and killed Saturday night as he and his friends played with a gun, the police said, and yesterday detectives were trying to determine how the shooting occurred. The boy, Oneck Simeon, a sixth grader who moved to Brooklyn from Haiti four years ago, ate a spaghetti dinner at his family's apartment at 1154 Nostrand
title: Playing With His Best Friend, A Sixth Grader Is Fatally Shot

body: A Brooklyn grand jury has cleared two police officers in the killing of an unarmed man whom they shot 18 times after he entered a stolen car they had under surveillance, prosecutors said yesterday. The plainclothes officers said they had opened fire because they thought that the man, Aswan Watson, 23, was reaching for a gun. When the car was
title: Two Officers Are Cleared In a Killing

body: TO express joy on a festive Jewish holiday, it is traditional to wear something new. Last week, for a Passover seder at her parents' home in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Suzy Berkowitz, 50, upheld tradition from head to toe. Exemplifying the Diana Vreeland dictum that elegance is restraint, she wore new Gucci pumps and a new Armani suit, hemmed
title: For Stylish Orthodox Women, Wigs That Aren't Wiggy

body: HOUSE tours, show houses and garden tours -- each a fund-raiser for a social-service organization, school or historic preservation group -- have started at country estates, urban apartments and backyard gardens from Boston to Delaware. New York City Flatbush, Brooklyn, Sunday -- A self-guided tour of 10 Victorian residences, including a 1903 Queen
title: Touring Gardens, Homes and Estates

body: To the Editor: The Greenways give the recreational cyclists an opportunity to communicate with some of the natural environment. All too often, though, that opportunity to enjoy nature's splendor is lost in the almost obsessive need to just cover the ground as quickly as possible. As a birdwatcher, I discovered a long time ago that I had to walk to
title: Cycling: Going Around Again

body: A 30-year-old Brooklyn man whom the police identified as a deacon at an Upper West Side church was charged yesterday in the 1995 death of his infant son. The man, Ricardo Black, was arrested at his home at 700 Ocean Avenue in East Flatbush yesterday and charged with second-degree murder with depraved indifference. He is a deacon at Zoe Ministries,
title: Church Deacon, 30, Is Charged In 1995 Death of His Infant Son

body: In this era of corporate cutting and trimming, there is a factory across from the Brooklyn Navy Yard that refuses to join in the downsizing binge. The maker of Sweet 'n Low, a $100 million company, keeps using clattery old equipment to preserve hundreds of neighborhood jobs. They pay well, dismiss rarely and know many of their employees personally.
title: A Family Business That Tries To Treat Workers Like Family

body: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN Jackie Robinson's Impact (Game Still in Progress) With the baseball season coming up, Long Island University is commemorating the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers, which broke major-league baseball's color barrier, in a three-day conference, ''Jackie Robinson: Race, Sports and the American
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A FEW weeks ago, two gardeners sat in the freezing sleet under a pergola in the Garden of the Golden Lions in central Harlem. They were grappling with the news that three community gardens on 121st Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and St. Nicholas Avenue, would have to close by the end of this month. title: Is This City Big Enough For Gardens And Houses?

body: THE Flatbush Development Corporation's annual house tour on April 27 will feature about a dozen buildings, but one of them is worth the trip all by itself -- the 1903 Japanese-style house at 131 Buckingham Road in Prospect Park South, perhaps New York's most unusual residence. Development south of Prospect Park picked up as rapid transit improved
title: Delicately Oriental, but 'Practical'

body: SHOPPING-CENTER developers love to fly. When they fly over central Queens and Brooklyn, they perceive in an instant what a research firm will later confirm in a study: In relation to the density of population, there is a shortage of the large modern supermarkets and big stores that shoppers find in the suburbs. A push is on to correct this
title: New Stores Raise Northern Boulevard's Profile

body: NYANN LODGE and Nicholas Ebanks, both 18, were ''gettin' giggy.'' That is, they were strutting down bustling Flatbush Avenue in central Brooklyn, adorned in the latest in hip-hop fashion, showing off their designer clothes and ogling pretty girls. title: What Price Tommy Hilfiger?

body: THE latest steps of the homecoming were the snazziest. Charles Jones from Brooklyn dribbled between his legs, dribbled behind his back and flitted through traffic for the crushing basket yesterday as Long Island University brought joy to downtown Brooklyn. The home team defeated Monmouth of New Jersey, 72-67, in the all-or-nothing shootout of the
title: New Heroes Bring Honor To Brooklyn

body: Hoping to cash in on the wave of retail development in downtown Brooklyn, directors of the Brooklyn Navy Yard industrial park said yesterday that they would seek development proposals for nine acres of the 300-acre city-owned park. While saying they would consider manufacturing or light industrial uses, directors of the Navy Yard said they hoped
title: Navy Yard Seeks Growth

body: March of Dimes Dance MONDAY -- The first Brooklyn Citizen of the Year Award will be presented to William C. Thompson Jr., the president of the New York City Board of Education, at a dinner-dance for the Greater New York Chapter of the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation. The black-tie evening, to be held at the Dime Savings Bank, 1 DeKalb
title: BENEFITS

body: THE problem that had stopped Pamela Henry from buying her apartment was her bankruptcy five years ago.. She was hesitant to talk about the circumstances -- they were still too painful -- but she wanted to give a boost to the privately run nonprofit group that helped her take on the banking bureaucracy and, finally, procure a mortgage. So she waded
title: Help Getting a Mortgage

body: Expecting an influx of new bus riders in July, when people can start transferring between buses and subways at no cost, officials are hiring 250 bus drivers and adding 205 extra buses to New York City streets. The changes will be most apparent along routes where many people take buses to or from the subway, like the B41 in Brooklyn, the Bx5 in the
title: 205 More Buses Ordered To Handle Free Transfers

body: THE lights in the cavernous freezer dimmed. The big fans fell silent. Alan Rosen, the third generation of Rosens to guard the venerable cheesecake tradition at Junior's restaurant on Flatbush Avenue, surveyed a scene more like Fort Knox than downtown Brooklyn: hundreds of pristine cheesecakes, stacked like gold bullion as far as the eye could see.
title: In Brooklyn, Passing the Torch of Success

body: An explosion in a power station under the Manhattan Bridge yesterday knocked out electricity to subway trains in both directions during the morning rush, stranding six trains on the bridge and jumbling service for thousands of commuters. There were no reports of injuries from the eruption, which occurred when a thick transformer wire in the York
title: Substation Explosion Strands Subway Trains on Manhattan Bridge

body: In a setback to neighborhood redevelopment efforts, Caldor Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest discount department store, announced yesterday that it was closing one store in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx as part of its continuing effort to climb out of bankruptcy proceedings. The stores, on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn and Fordham Road in the
title: Caldor, in 700-Job Trim, Says It Will Close 2 Stores

body: MARX-Elaine H. (nee Silverman). Devoted mother of Barry and his wife Allyn, Philip and his wife Sheryl, David and his wife Robin. Adoring grandmother of Mellisa, Deborah and Danny. body: Ed Powell groaned when he saw a police officer escorting a teen-ager he knew out of the Flatbush branch of the Brooklyn Public Library in December. Mr. Powell, whose Umma Group Inc. organizes civilian anticrime patrols in the neighborhood, knew that the young man had once worked as a look-out for a major drug dealer. He could only imagine what the
title: A Shortage of Terminals Spells Computer Access Denied

body: SUNNYSIDE Banker Gets a Lucky Strike, But He Is Not Too Happy A young banker is given the Midas touch, to his regret, in ''Un Golpe de Suerte'' (''A Stroke of Luck''), a romantic comedy by the Spanish playwright Juan Jose Alonso Milan that has had its run extended at the Thalia Spanish Theater. The lead actor, Fermin Suarez, has been nominated for
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: For Anxious Children, This Salon Makes the Cut A friend of Cozy Wolan took her 2-year-old nephew along when she went to get her hair cut at a fancy salon. The friend thought it would be fun to have the little boy's hair cut too. And for $80, a stylist started snipping away. But then the child started to cry, and some of the salon's customers asked
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.

body: After years of having Sunday morning services consistently attract fewer than a dozen worshipers, the Rev. William R. Nye and his tiny congregation decided last spring that the end had finally come. Pastor Nye and the 10 remaining members of the All Souls Universalist Church voted to sell their church at Ditmas and Ocean Avenues and merge with an
title: Congregation Is Small but Gift Is Still Grand

body: GRANT-David. On February 7, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Pauline. Loving father of Stephen and Robert. Devoted to his daughters-in-law Ruth and Bridget and to his grandchildren: Joseph, Laura, Thomas, Anna, Neil and Jane. He adored his family and was loved and cherished by them for his good humor and kindness. We shall miss him greatly. Services
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GRANT, DAVID

body: WAGNER-Harold. Devoted husband of Bea (nee Siegel). Beloved father of Jeffrey, Stuart and Marc. Fond father-in-law of Bette, Dolores and Ellen. Loving grandfather and great grandfather. Dear brother of Miriam Lennon, Hannah Eichler and the late Milton Wagner. Fond uncle. In repose at Parkside, 2576 Flatbush Avenue at Kings Plaza, Brooklyn. Services
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WAGNER, HAROLD

body: LEVINE-Erna. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Carol L. Cohen and Lynn Levine and mother-in-law of Michael Cohen and Cliff Adler. Cherished grandmother of Gregg and Brook. Devoted sister of Harry Hirschmann, Richard Hirschmann, Ilsa Rosenbaum and Lotte Koesten. Services today, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVINE, ERNA

body: In a recent basketball game in their cramped gym on Flatbush Avenue, the Long Island University Blackbirds were trailing the Monmouth College Hawks by 6 points with five minutes left to play. Ray Haskins, the L.I.U. coach, shook his head, called a timeout and tried to motivate his shaken squad. The crowd, numbed by a late scoring spurt by the
title: A Master Organist's Music to Dunk By

body: AT Walton High School in the Bronx, Andrean Russell was the student her peers went to when they wanted their hair braided. Over the years, her clientele grew, along with her reputation as a skilled braider. Relatives and friends have sat patiently at Ms. Russell's knee for hours while she weaved African-inspired braids into hair once styled with
title: The Battle of the Braid Brigade

body: A small water-main break in Brooklyn yesterday had the ripple effect of disrupting subway service all the way into Manhattan yesterday, as transit officials shut down parts of two lines for nine hours, fearing that two brownstones might collapse. When water to the broken main was shut off shortly after noon, the front stoops and the facade of the
title: Small Water Line Break Makes Torrent of Trouble

body: GOLDMAN-David N. Beloved husband of the late Miriam, dear father of Stanley, Lester, and Pauline Walters. Adored grandfather of Michael, Howard and Jennifer. Services on Thursday, 11:30 A.M. ''Parkside Chapels'', 2576 Flatbush Avenue (Avenue U), Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GOLDMAN, DAVID N.

body: CATHY JONES sat in the stands last week for a basketball game at Long Island University on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn to watch her son, Charles, who, to the surprise of many, is the leading scorer in the nation. He was playing in an unlikely arena that was once the Paramount Theater, and which still has the old, ornate gilded ceiling and rococo
title: All the Potential a Faithful Mother Can Foster

body: Fighting the deep-January blues with children doesn't seem easy at first if you live in New York City. The parks can feel as cold as Siberia, and skating arenas are often too jammed for figure-eights. And have you noticed the lines at the movies? If only we were bears and could sleep until spring. Yet an eclectic array of remedies exists. Here is
title: For Children

body: Scattered by time and circumstance to new hometowns across the nation, many former New Yorkers preserve a link to the great glittering metropolis by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Their donations -- with postmarks from Wisconsin to Texas, California to Massachusetts -- reach their former neighbors in the five boroughs who
title: Former Neighbors Show Care From Afar

body: As the elevated No. 7 IRT train slowed to its last stop in Queens some years ago, John P. Watts used to look outside fondly toward the northern end of Main Street. Against the nighttime sky, above the low rooftops of downtown Flushing where tall buildings with Chinese and Korean signs have since risen, he would pick out the red light of the RKO
title: The Politics of Nostalgia Grows Bitter Over a Movie Palace in Flushing

body: Someday, Detective Bobby Sommer said, in his less than tidy second-floor office in the 61st Precinct station house in Coney Island, he hopes to get a call about Sergei Kobozev. He said he was practically certain, though, that the call would not come from Mr. Kobozev himself, a 6-foot-1, 190-pound Russian boxer who left a garage in Flatbush,
title: A Year After Sergei Kobozev Vanished, An Investigator Goes Yet Another Round

body: NEW YORK Stalking the Shadow of a Boxer Someday, Detective Bobby Sommer says, he hopes to get a call about Sergei Kobozev, a 6-foot-1, 190-pound Russian boxer who left a garage in Flatbush, Brooklyn, one evening in November 1995 and has not been heard from since. For more than a year, Detective Sommer has knocked on doors of stores and apartments
title: METRO DIGEST

body: SILSBE - Seymour. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Robert and Jeanmarie, James and Mindy. Adored grandfather of Robert, Ashley, Ryan, Michelle and Jessica. Service today, 1 PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SILSBE, SEYMOUR

body: BLUTHAL - Rose. Devoted wife to the late Joseph, loving mother of Judith and Stanley Hoffman, Lois and Morton Turchin and Pepi and Irwin Streiff. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Funeral services Friday, 11:30 AM at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BLUTHAL, ROSE

body: IN its drive to build affordable homes in some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, the Giuliani administration has sounded the death knell for hundreds of community gardens that have, over the last 20 years, risen out of the rubble and rats of bankrupt, abandoned land. Starting this spring, 25 gardens in Harlem and Coney Island will be bulldozed
title: Houses Before Gardens, The City Decides

body: WASSERSTEIN - Eve. Loving wife of the late Morris. Beloved mother of Donald and Malcolm Eisenberg. Cherished grandmother of Lynn, Gail, James, Lisa, Jonathan and Michael. Adoring great-grandmother of Lindsay, Larry and Meredith. Devoted sister to Isabel Klein. Funeral services Friday, 9:45 AM, at IJ. Morris, Inc. 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WASSERSTEIN, EVE

body: BOYKOFF - Emanuel. Of Boca Raton, Fl, formerly of Jamaica Estates, NY. Beloved husband of Dorq. Devoted father of Joan Baron and Carolyn Hittleman. Loving grandfather of Michael and Jonathan Baron and Isabel Hittleman. Service will be 12:30 today, Jan 9, 1997, at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BOYKOFF, EMANUEL

body: EISENBERG - Eve. Cherished wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Donald and Malcolm. Beloved grandmother of Lynn, Gail, James, Lisa, Jonathan and Michael. Adoring great-grandmother of Lindsay, Larry and Meredith. Devoted sister to Isabel Klein. Funeral services Friday, 9:45 AM, at IJ. Morris Inc. 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths EISENBERG, EVE

body: AN O'Malley put a ''for sale'' sign on the Dodgers yesterday -- 40 years too late for Brooklyn. But from Flatbush to Bensonhurst, from Red Hook to Coney Island, anyone who remembered how the late Walter O'Malley hijacked the Dodgers to Los Angeles after the 1957 season had to be smirking when they learned of the devotion of his son, Peter O'Malley,
title: Brooklyn Has a Reason To Smirk

body: As soon as the reports of the firefighter's death began to circulate, colleagues from all over Brooklyn began calling Hook and Ladder Company 174 in East Flatbush. The callers volunteered to fill in for members of Ladder Company 174 so they could be free to tend to their grief and to take the long, sad drive to Suffolk County, where they paid their
title: For Firefighters, Grief Over a Colleague Killed While Jogging

body: UPPER EAST SIDE Never Too Soon to Prepare For Next New Year's Eve New Year's Day celebrations may be over but you can still dance the night away at the 92d Street Y's Saturday Night Ballroom Party. At this week's party, the center will offer lessons in swing and fox trot, followed by social dancing. Teachers from the Sandra Cameron Dance Center
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: James Halversen, a New York City firefighter, drove away from his Long Island home at 9:30 P.M. on Friday, his golden retriever by his side, and headed for a high school track where he often jogged in the evening. Three hours later, his wife, Rosalie, eight months pregnant with twins, found her husband lying unconscious on the track at Centereach
title: New York City Firefighter Killed While Jogging Near His L.I. Home

body: On the surface, the fight doesn't seem fair. Triangle Sports's inventory is respectable. The Sports Authority's inventory is frightening. Triangle, an 80-year-old, family-run business, offers more than 50 kinds of baseball gloves. The Sports Authority, a nationwide chain with a gargantuan store in the new Atlantic Center mall, offers more than 100.
title: In the Shadow of the Mall, Little Stores Find Some Light

body: WASSERMAN - Abraham. December 30, 1996, age 90 years, of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Ida for sixty-six years. Brother of Samuel and Ruth Wasserman of Silver Spring, Maryland. Father of Edel and Zelda, Rhoda and Charles, and Malvina; grandfather of Stepehn Wasserman, Diane and Matthew Feldman, Ellen and Jim Hamlin, Terry and Jeff
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WASSERMAN, ABRAHAM
